text: [Music]
my name is Adam oler I'm a post-doctoral
scholar in the amp lab been here about a
year and a half the Inception of the
carrot project came about because we
were starting to see people talk about
energy problems on their cell phones
people were running out of battery and
didn't have the information that they
need to do something about this and so
we started looking at ways of not only
characterizing how much energy is being
used but whether that energy use is
normal and the key thing that we had to
do to make that work was to collect data
from a very large number of devices and
aggregate that all and run an analysis
on
it cared is an app that tells you what's
using energy on your mobile device and
what you can do to improve your battery
life so I'll give you specific
recommendations that are personalized
for your device using all the
information that we've collected over
all the devices that are running carot
and how much improvement you should
expect by taking certain actions we
launched carat this year and we very
quickly were featured on Tech Crunch and
so a great number of people learned
about the project all of a sudden and we
were expecting to maybe have a thousand
or so users at the high end within 24
hours about 24 other news sources picked
up the story and by the next morning we
had more than 100,000 people using
carrot and now we're approaching about
half a million users which was something
that we never
expected the devices that have Carro
installed report their data to a backend
server uh that runs a load balancer on
AWS spreads it out to five different
servers that then store the data in S3
and Dynamo DB and the analysis runs on a
set of ec2 instances that we launch
perform the analysis and then shut down
in addition to telling you what is using
energy and whether or not that's normal
it'll also quantify both how much energy
it thinks that this app is using and
gives an error and a confidence
associated with
it probably the the greatest advantage
that we've gotten from AWS is the
flexibility so we had thought that we
were only going to have maybe 1 to
10,000 users on the high end and so if
we had provision this and bought our own
cluster um then within 24 hours of
launching we would have already been
overwhelmed and it would have taken us a
long time to respond to this with AWS we
could simply tell the load balancer that
we wanted to spread it out to a larger
number of servers and we would just
launch more ec2 instances or ones with
more memory when we needed to run the
analysis on this much greater number of
users than we had anticipated and so
instead we could focus more on the
research and scaling the actual
mathematics of the analysis and the uh
customer service I think carrot has the
property that we were able to turn into
something that people could actually
just use on their in their daily lives
we've gotten a lot of great feedback
from people that Express excitement
about having control over something that
previous iously was inaccessible to
them I'm excited about the project I
love it I think we've been able to do
things with carrot that uh I wasn't able
to do with any of the other projects we
worked on I think in reality especially
for projects like ours their research um
it would never have been possible for us
to know beforehand exactly what we would
need and so having the ability to get
that flexibility was really the key to
making this
[Music]
work
[Music]
